Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside decorated with representation of couchant lion and a cross-shaped symbol (debased version of the hieroglyph Kheper?) above back and neb-basket sign underneath; motif incised, rather than stamped; pierced through diameter; glaze surface survives as thin buff to greenish layer in some parts; underneath this layer greyish/buff tinge surface; core of yellowish tinge, with porous, rough texture; surface worn off.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This scarab is published as coming from Naukratis (Budge 1893, no. 365). Scarabs and scaraboids with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 34-45). This scaraboid is close to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A72a). Let's note that the motif on the underside is incised, not stamped, so it does not share the technical characteristics as defined in Gorton's type XXVIII. For close types of scaraboids: BM 1886,0401.1627; Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H3807. Budge, E.A.W. 1893, Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Budge 1893b / Catalogue of the Egyptian collection in the Fitzwilliam Museum (no. 365)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.006) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather poor, surface very worn off
